audience: High school students preparing for the SAT (Reading & Writing)

teacher_notes.pacing: 60 minutes; 3 sections with quick practice and feedback.
teacher_notes.materials: Slide deck with example transitions, sample sources for synthesis, and style/tone examples.
teacher_notes.assessment: Unit check and review of edited sentences in guided practice.

learning_objectives: Choose precise transitions that reflect logic between ideas.
Synthesize information from a short source set to support a claim.
Maintain consistent style and tone appropriate to context.

structure.title: Transitions
objectives: Match transition type to relationship (addition, contrast, cause).
Eliminate grammatically fine but illogical connectors.
Test by paraphrasing the link in simple words.

lecture_script.script: Identify the relationship between sentences first. Then pick a transition that states that relationship-no fancier than needed.
We’ll replace vague connectors with specific ones that show contrast or cause-and-effect.
State the link in two words: ‘therefore’ or ‘however’? Choose accordingly.

worked_example.passage: The proposal is affordable; however, it lacks a plan for maintenance costs after year one.
worked_example.question: Which transition best fits the relationship?
worked_example.explanation: The second clause contrasts a strength with a weakness; ‘however’ signals contrast.

practice_set.passage: The solar array cut energy use by 20%; therefore, monthly costs fell noticeably.
practice_set.question: The transition primarily shows

structure.title: Rhetorical Synthesis
objectives: Select evidence that best supports a stated claim from multiple sources.
Combine concise paraphrases from two brief sources.

lecture_script.script: Underline the claim, then pick data that directly advances that claim. If it doesn’t support, it doesn’t belong.
Claim: school gardens improve nutrition. Source A shows increased veggie intake; Source B shows more students trying new produce-both support the claim.
Which source sentence actually proves the claim? Give the letter only.

worked_example.passage: Claim: Later school start times improve attendance. Source 1: After shifting to 8:45 a.m., tardies fell by 30%. Source 2: Students reported feeling more rested.
worked_example.question: Which statement best supports the claim?

options.B: Tardies fell by 30% after a later start.

worked_example.explanation: The 30% drop in tardies directly supports improved attendance.

practice_set.passage: Claim: Adding shade trees lowers building energy use. Source A: Shaded walls absorb less heat. Source B: Meter readings fell 12% after tree planting.
practice_set.question: Which choice best supports the claim?

structure.title: Style & Tone
objectives: Maintain a consistent formal or informal tone.
Choose concise, precise phrasing over wordiness.
Avoid slang or jargon that clashes with context.

lecture_script.script: Match the register to the audience. Academic contexts prefer concise and neutral phrasing.
We’ll revise sentences to remove wordiness and adjust tone from casual to formal.
Is this phrase too casual for a report? Answer yes or no.

worked_example.passage: Original: The experiment was kind of a big deal because it, like, showed cool results. Revision options vary in formality and precision.
worked_example.question: Which revision maintains an appropriately formal tone?

options.A: The experiment was kinda big ‘cause it showed cool results.
options.B: The experiment was important because it demonstrated clear results.
options.C: The experiment was, you know, interesting.
options.D: The experiment was epic and wild.

worked_example.explanation: Option B is concise and formal, avoiding slang and vagueness.

practice_set.passage: Choose the most concise, formal option to complete: ‘The committee decided to ___ the plan for clarity.’
practice_set.question: Which choice best fits?

options.B: completely and totally overhaul in a manner that is thorough
evidence that advances the stated claim

homework: Edit a paragraph by replacing three weak transitions with precise ones and justify each choice.
From two short sources, select two sentences that best support a given claim.
Revise five sentences to align tone with a formal report.
